The **2018 NFL season** is the 99th season of the [National Football
League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") (NFL). The
season began on September 6, 2018 with the [NFL Kickoff
Game](/wiki/NFL_Kickoff_Game "NFL Kickoff Game") with the defending [Super
Bowl LII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LII "Super Bowl LII") champion [Philadelphia
Eagles](/wiki/2018_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2018 Philadelphia Eagles
season") defeating the [Atlanta Falcons](/wiki/2018_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2018 Atlanta Falcons season") 18–12. The season will conclude with [Super
Bowl LIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LIII "Super Bowl LIII"), the league's championship
game, on February 3, 2019 at [Mercedes-Benz Stadium](/wiki/Mercedes-
Benz_Stadium "Mercedes-Benz Stadium") in [Atlanta, Georgia](/wiki/Atlanta
"Atlanta").

## Player
movement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Player movement")]

The 2018 NFL League year and trading period began on March 14. On March 9,
clubs were allowed to exercise options for 2018 on players who have option
clauses in their contracts, submit qualifying offers to their pending
restricted free agents and submit a Minimum Salary Tender to retain exclusive
negotiating rights to their players with expiring 2017 contracts and who have
fewer than three accrued seasons of free agent credit. Teams were required to
be under the salary cap using the "Top-51" definition (in which the 51 highest
paid-players on the team's payroll must have a combined salary cap hit below
the actual cap). On March 12, clubs were allowed to contact and enter into
contract negotiations with the agents of players who were set to become
unrestricted free agents.

### Free
agency[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Free agency")]

Over 550 players were eligible for some form of free agency during the free
agency period.[1] Notable players to change teams include:

  * Quarterbacks [Sam Bradford](/wiki/Sam_Bradford "Sam Bradford") (Minnesota to Arizona), [Kirk Cousins](/wiki/Kirk_Cousins "Kirk Cousins") (Washington to Minnesota), [Case Keenum](/wiki/Case_Keenum "Case Keenum") (Minnesota to Denver), and [AJ McCarron](/wiki/AJ_McCarron "AJ McCarron") (Cincinnati to Buffalo).
  * Running backs [Isaiah Crowell](/wiki/Isaiah_Crowell "Isaiah Crowell") (Cleveland to New York Jets), [Carlos Hyde](/wiki/Carlos_Hyde "Carlos Hyde") (San Francisco to Cleveland), [Frank Gore](/wiki/Frank_Gore "Frank Gore") (Indianapolis to Miami), [Dion Lewis](/wiki/Dion_Lewis "Dion Lewis") (New England to Tennessee), [Jerick McKinnon](/wiki/Jerick_McKinnon "Jerick McKinnon") (Minnesota to San Francisco), and [Adrian Peterson](/wiki/Adrian_Peterson "Adrian Peterson") (Arizona to Washington)
  * Wide receivers [Danny Amendola](/wiki/Danny_Amendola "Danny Amendola") (New England to Miami), [Allen Hurns](/wiki/Allen_Hurns "Allen Hurns") (Jacksonville to Dallas), [Jordy Nelson](/wiki/Jordy_Nelson "Jordy Nelson") (Green Bay to Oakland), [Allen Robinson](/wiki/Allen_Robinson "Allen Robinson") (Jacksonville to Chicago), and [Sammy Watkins](/wiki/Sammy_Watkins_\(American_football\) "Sammy Watkins \(American football\)") (Los Angeles Rams to Kansas City)
  * Tight ends [Jimmy Graham](/wiki/Jimmy_Graham "Jimmy Graham") (Seattle to Green Bay), [Austin Seferian-Jenkins](/wiki/Austin_Seferian-Jenkins "Austin Seferian-Jenkins") (New York Jets to Jacksonville), and [Marcedes Lewis](/wiki/Marcedes_Lewis "Marcedes Lewis") (Jacksonville to Green Bay)
  * Offensive linemen [Cameron Fleming](/wiki/Cameron_Fleming "Cameron Fleming") (New England to Dallas), [Andrew Norwell](/wiki/Andrew_Norwell "Andrew Norwell") (Carolina to Jacksonville), [Mike Pouncey](/wiki/Mike_Pouncey "Mike Pouncey") (Miami to Los Angeles Chargers), [Justin Pugh](/wiki/Justin_Pugh "Justin Pugh") (New York Giants to Arizona), [Weston Richburg](/wiki/Weston_Richburg "Weston Richburg") (New York Giants to San Francisco), [Nate Solder](/wiki/Nate_Solder "Nate Solder") (New England to New York Giants), [Josh Sitton](/wiki/Josh_Sitton "Josh Sitton") (Chicago to Miami), and [Travis Swanson](/wiki/Travis_Swanson "Travis Swanson") (Detroit to New York Jets)
  * Defensive linemen [Adrian Clayborn](/wiki/Adrian_Clayborn "Adrian Clayborn") (Atlanta to New England), [Vinny Curry](/wiki/Vinny_Curry "Vinny Curry") (Philadelphia to Tampa Bay), [Sheldon Richardson](/wiki/Sheldon_Richardson "Sheldon Richardson") (Seattle to Minnesota), [Ndamukong Suh](/wiki/Ndamukong_Suh "Ndamukong Suh") (Miami to Los Angeles Rams), [Star Lotulelei](/wiki/Star_Lotulelei "Star Lotulelei") (Carolina to Buffalo), and [Muhammad Wilkerson](/wiki/Muhammad_Wilkerson "Muhammad Wilkerson") (New York Jets to Green Bay)
  * Linebackers [Demario Davis](/wiki/Demario_Davis "Demario Davis") (New York Jets to New Orleans), [Trent Murphy](/wiki/Trent_Murphy "Trent Murphy") (Washington to Buffalo), [Tahir Whitehead](/wiki/Tahir_Whitehead "Tahir Whitehead") (Detroit to Oakland), and [Avery Williamson](/wiki/Avery_Williamson "Avery Williamson") (Tennessee to New York Jets)
  * Defensive backs [Malcolm Butler](/wiki/Malcolm_Butler "Malcolm Butler") (New England to Tennessee), [Morgan Burnett](/wiki/Morgan_Burnett "Morgan Burnett") (Green Bay to Pittsburgh), [T. J. Carrie](/wiki/T._J._Carrie "T. J. Carrie") (Oakland to Cleveland), [Ross Cockrell](/wiki/Ross_Cockrell "Ross Cockrell") (New York Giants to Carolina), [E. J. Gaines](/wiki/E._J._Gaines "E. J. Gaines") (Buffalo to Cleveland), [Marcus Gilchrist](/wiki/Marcus_Gilchrist "Marcus Gilchrist") (Houston to Oakland), [Trumaine Johnson](/wiki/Trumaine_Johnson_\(cornerback\) "Trumaine Johnson \(cornerback\)") (Los Angeles Rams to New York Jets), [Tyrann Mathieu](/wiki/Tyrann_Mathieu "Tyrann Mathieu") (Arizona to Houston), [Rashaan Melvin](/wiki/Rashaan_Melvin "Rashaan Melvin") (Indianapolis to Oakland), [Eric Reid](/wiki/Eric_Reid_\(American_football\) "Eric Reid \(American football\)") (San Francisco To Carolina), [Patrick Robinson](/wiki/Patrick_Robinson_\(cornerback\) "Patrick Robinson \(cornerback\)") (Philadelphia to New Orleans), and [Richard Sherman](/wiki/Richard_Sherman_\(American_football\) "Richard Sherman \(American football\)") (Seattle to San Francisco)
  * Kicker [Sebastian Janikowski](/wiki/Sebastian_Janikowski "Sebastian Janikowski") (Oakland to Seattle)
  * Punter [Marquette King](/wiki/Marquette_King "Marquette King") (Oakland to Denver)

###
Retirements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Retirements")]

  * [Kam Chancellor](/wiki/Kam_Chancellor "Kam Chancellor"): The four-time Pro Bowler and two-time second team All-Pro safety retired July 1 due to a neck injury. He played his entire eight-year career with the [Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks "Seattle Seahawks").
  * [Antonio Cromartie](/wiki/Antonio_Cromartie "Antonio Cromartie"): The four-time Pro Bowler and one-time All-Pro cornerback, who shares the league record for most yards gained on a play (109 on a missed field goal return) and led the league in interceptions in 2008, announced his retirement after an 11-year career. Cromartie played for the then-San Diego Chargers, New York Jets, Arizona Cardinals, and Indianapolis Colts over the course of his career, before spending the entire 2017 season as an unsigned free agent.[30]
  * [Dwight Freeney](/wiki/Dwight_Freeney "Dwight Freeney"): The 16-year veteran defensive end, who spent most of his career with the [Indianapolis Colts](/wiki/Indianapolis_Colts "Indianapolis Colts"), retired April 19. He appeared in seven Pro Bowls, was a four-time All-Pro and led the NFL in sacks during the 2004 season.[31]
  * [James Harrison](/wiki/James_Harrison_\(American_football\) "James Harrison \(American football\)"): The 15-year NFL veteran linebacker, four-time All-Pro, and five-time Pro Bowler who spent the peak of his career with the [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") announced his retirement, at the age of 39, on April 16.[32]
  * [Devin Hester](/wiki/Devin_Hester "Devin Hester"): The four-time Pro Bowler and three-time All-Pro [return specialist](/wiki/Return_specialist "Return specialist") holds the NFL record for most all-time return touchdowns (punt and kickoff combined) and most all-time punt return touchdowns.[33] He is widely regarded as one of the best return specialists in NFL history, and was the first person to return the opening kick of the [Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLI "Super Bowl XLI") back for a touchdown. Hester, who had spent 2017 out of football, played 11 seasons in the NFL, the majority of them with the [Chicago Bears](/wiki/Chicago_Bears "Chicago Bears").[34][35][36]
  * [Richie Incognito](/wiki/Richie_Incognito "Richie Incognito") announced his retirement April 10. The retirement was part of a string of [erratic behavior and inconsistent statements](/wiki/Richie_Incognito#2017_season "Richie Incognito") on Incognito's part, the only consistent thread being an ongoing contract dispute with his current team, the [Buffalo Bills](/wiki/Buffalo_Bills "Buffalo Bills"), who have listed him as retired on their roster. Incognito has appeared in four Pro Bowls over the course of a 12-season career with the Bills, [Miami Dolphins](/wiki/Miami_Dolphins "Miami Dolphins") and then-[St. Louis Rams](/wiki/St._Louis_Rams "St. Louis Rams"), with most of his success coming in Buffalo. He was released from his contract on May 21 and is free to sign with any team.
  * [Nick Mangold](/wiki/Nick_Mangold "Nick Mangold"): The seven-time Pro Bowler and three-time All-Pro retired after 11 seasons, all with the [New York Jets](/wiki/New_York_Jets "New York Jets"). He had spent the 2017 season out of football after the Jets released him.[37]
  * [Carson Palmer](/wiki/Carson_Palmer "Carson Palmer"): The 38 year old quarterback for the [Arizona Cardinals](/wiki/Arizona_Cardinals "Arizona Cardinals"), who had previously played on the [Cincinnati Bengals](/wiki/Cincinnati_Bengals "Cincinnati Bengals") (who drafted Palmer [first overall](/wiki/List_of_first_overall_National_Football_League_draft_picks "List of first overall National Football League draft picks") in [2003](/wiki/2003_NFL_Draft "2003 NFL Draft")) and [Oakland Raiders](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland Raiders"), retired after the 2017 season. The 2002 [Heisman Trophy](/wiki/Heisman_Trophy "Heisman Trophy") winner appeared in three Pro Bowls, was a second team [All-Pro](/wiki/All-Pro "All-Pro") in 2015, and led the NFL in passing yards in 2005.[38][39]
  * [Darrelle Revis](/wiki/Darrelle_Revis "Darrelle Revis"): The seven-time Pro Bowler and four-time All-Pro spent 11 seasons in the NFL, eight of them with the [New York Jets](/wiki/New_York_Jets "New York Jets"). At his peak, he was one of the most dominant, well-paid, and awarded cornerbacks in the league (only [Deion Sanders](/wiki/Deion_Sanders "Deion Sanders") has had more All-Pro nominations at the position); his level of play had diminished rapidly by the time of his retirement. He announced his retirement July 18.[40]
  * [Joe Thomas](/wiki/Joe_Thomas_\(offensive_tackle\) "Joe Thomas \(offensive tackle\)"): The ten-time [Pro Bowler](/wiki/Pro_Bowl "Pro Bowl") and seven-time All-Pro offensive tackle retired after an 11-year career with the [Cleveland Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns"), a career in which he spent much of that time as the Browns' [franchise player](/wiki/Franchise_player "Franchise player") in an era where the team otherwise performed poorly on the field.[41] A deteriorating left knee contributed to Thomas's retirement.[42]
  * [Jason Witten](/wiki/Jason_Witten "Jason Witten"): The eleven time [Pro Bowler](/wiki/Pro_Bowl "Pro Bowl") and two time First-team All-Pro Tight end played 15 seasons, all with the [Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys"). He ranks second all time among tight ends in career receptions and receiving yards. He will be working for [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN") as their _[Monday Night Football](/wiki/Monday_Night_Football "Monday Night Football")_ color commentator.[43]

### Draft[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Draft")]

Further information: [2018 NFL Draft](/wiki/2018_NFL_Draft "2018 NFL Draft")

The [2018 NFL Draft](/wiki/2018_NFL_Draft "2018 NFL Draft") was held from
April 26 to 28 at [AT&T Stadium](/wiki/AT%26T_Stadium "AT&T Stadium") in
[Arlington, Texas](/wiki/Arlington,_Texas "Arlington, Texas"). This was the
first draft to take place in an NFL stadium, and the first to be held in
Texas.[65] The [Cleveland Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns")
selected [Baker Mayfield](/wiki/Baker_Mayfield "Baker Mayfield") with the
[first overall pick](/wiki/List_of_NFL_first_overall_draft_choices "List of
NFL first overall draft choices").

## Officiating
changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Officiating changes")]

### Offseason[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Offseason")]

Four referees retired during the 2018 off-season, the most to do so since
records on the statistics have been kept.[66]

  * [Ed Hochuli](/wiki/Ed_Hochuli "Ed Hochuli"): At the time of his retirement, Hochuli was the league's longest-tenured referee, having served with the league for 28 seasons, 26 as a head referee. He was succeeded by his son, [Shawn Hochuli](/wiki/Shawn_Hochuli "Shawn Hochuli").[67]
  * [Terry McAulay](/wiki/Terry_McAulay "Terry McAulay"): McAulay spent 20 seasons as an official, 17 as a head referee, and officiated three [Super Bowls](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl"). McAulay will work as a rules analyst for NBC's _[Sunday Night Football](/wiki/NBC_Sunday_Night_Football "NBC Sunday Night Football")_.[66] [Shawn Smith](/wiki/Shawn_Smith_\(American_football\) "Shawn Smith \(American football\)"), an umpire since [2015](/wiki/2015_NFL_season "2015 NFL season"), was promoted to replace McAulay.[68][69]
  * [Gene Steratore](/wiki/Gene_Steratore "Gene Steratore"): Steratore spent 15 seasons as an official and was the referee of [Super Bowl LII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LII "Super Bowl LII"). Staratore was involved in the controversial ruling known as the [Calvin Johnson](/wiki/Calvin_Johnson "Calvin Johnson") rule, as well as the infamous use of an index card during a game between the [Oakland Raiders](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland Raiders") and [Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys"). He was one of two officials who also covered [NCAA](/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association "National Collegiate Athletic Association") [Division I](/wiki/College_basketball#NCAA_Division_I "College basketball") basketball games. Steratore accepted an offer from CBS to fill its rules analyst position, which had been vacant since 2015.[66] Umpire [Clay Martin](/wiki/Clay_Martin "Clay Martin") was promoted to referee to replace Steratore.[70]
  * [Jeff Triplette](/wiki/Jeff_Triplette "Jeff Triplette"): Triplette had spent 22 years as an official with the NFL, 19 as a head referee. [Alex Kemp](/wiki/Alex_Kemp_\(American_football_official\) "Alex Kemp \(American football official\)") replaced Triplette.[67]

In total, 10 officials left the league in the offseason, and 7 were hired.
Four officials were promoted to the referee position.[71]

### In-season[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: In-season")]

Down judge Hugo Cruz was fired for performance-related issues culminating with
a missed false start during a Week 6 game between the [Los Angeles
Chargers](/wiki/2018_Los_Angeles_Chargers_season "2018 Los Angeles Chargers
season") and [Cleveland Browns](/wiki/2018_Cleveland_Browns_season "2018
Cleveland Browns season"). It was the first time in the [Super
Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl") era that an official was dismissed in-
season.[72]

## Rule
changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Rule changes")]

The following playing rule changes have been approved by the Competition
Committee for the 2018 season:[73]

  * Make permanent the current rule that changes the spot of the ball after a touchback on a kickoff to the 25-yard line. Prior to [2017](/wiki/2017_NFL_season "2017 NFL season"), the ball was placed at the 20-yard line.
  * Update the standards for a "catch" to have: 
    * Two feet down or any body part other than the hands
    * Control of the ball
    * Make a "football move" such as making a 3rd step, reaching/extending to the line to gain, tucking the ball away, warding off defensive players, or have the ability to perform such an act.

    The rule for receivers who were going to the ground during the catch process has been deleted. This is in response to several issues regarding the "going to the ground" rule, especially catches by [Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys") WR [Dez Bryant](/wiki/Dez_Bryant "Dez Bryant") in the 2014 NFL playoffs and one by [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") TE [Jesse James](/wiki/Jesse_James_\(American_football\) "Jesse James \(American football\)") in 2017 that were overturned due to this rule.
  * Allow a designated member of the officiating department (for 2018, NFL Senior VP of Officiating Al Riveron) to instruct game officials to disqualify any player who commits a flagrant non-football act on the field for a foul called on the field. This is in response to a situation where [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") tight end [Rob Gronkowski](/wiki/Rob_Gronkowski "Rob Gronkowski") intentionally inflicted a late hit on [Buffalo Bills](/wiki/Buffalo_Bills "Buffalo Bills") defensive back [Tre'Davious White](/wiki/Tre%27Davious_White "Tre'Davious White") causing a concussion to White. Gronkowski was not ejected for the foul on the field, but did receive a one-game suspension after the NFL's review of the play.
  * Illegally batting a ball on a scrimmage down will incur a loss of down in addition to the previous 10-yard penalty.
  * In overtime, when a team is ahead by 3 points, a down will run to its conclusion and all applicable points will score, even if there is a loss of possession. Previously, the offense of the trailing team could not legally score if they lost and regained possession and reached the opponent's end zone all on the same play. The rule remains that if there is a double change of possession on a play with one team in the lead, it is the last play of the game.
  * If a team scores a touchdown on the final play of regulation which gives them the victory, no extra-point conversion try will be needed.[74]
  * A quarterback may slide either head first or feet first to be considered giving himself up on the play, and he is afforded all protections previously provided to a quarterback sliding feet first.

The following bylaws and resolutions were passed:[75]

  * Make permanent the liberalization of workout rules for draft prospects.
  * For a one-year trial period, liberalize the rules for re-signing a player on waivers.
  * Players on injured reserve can be traded.
  * Players with injuries deemed major can be placed directly on injured reserve without clearing waivers.
  * The 10-day postseason waiver claiming period has been reduced to 1 day.
  * Players can be activated from injured reserve after eight games instead of eight weeks.
  * Teams have seven business days to complete an injury settlement instead of five.
  * Players in certain reserve list categories cannot be reinstated after a team's week 13 game. This restriction was previously applied to the last 30 days of the regular season.
  * Clarify roster procedures for players with military obligations.
  * For a one-year trial period, teams may contact a player who has been publicly announced to be released before the NFL lists the transaction on a Player Personnel Notice.

The following changes to the kickoff rules were approved at the NFL Spring
Owners' Meeting on May 23, 2018:[76]

  * Players are required to line up for the kickoff as follows: 
    * Five players on the kicking team must be on either side of the kicker
    * Two players on each side must be lined up outside of the numbers and two additional players on each side must be lined up between the numbers and the hashmarks
    * Players on the kicking team (excluding the kicker) may only line up within one yard of the kickoff spot (currently this is limited to five yards)
    * The receiving team must have eight players in a fifteen-yard "set-up zone" (from the restraining line ten yards from the kickoff spot, fifteen yards back)
  * No wedge blocks. Players would only be able to do a double-team block within the "set-up zone".
  * Blocking is prohibited inside the restraining zone (10 yards from the kickoff spot) until the ball touches the ground or is touched in the field of play.
  * Once a kickoff lands in the end zone, it would become an automatic touchback. Players will no longer have to "kneel" in the end zone to stop the play.
  * Any player(s) being disqualified are subject to replay review.
  * It is now a foul (15 yards) for players to lower their helmet to initiate and make contact with an opposing player. The fouling player risks disqualification if: 
    * Player lowers his helmet to establish a linear body posture prior to initiating or making contact with the helmet
    * Player delivering the blow had an unobstructed path to his opponent
    * Contact was clearly avoidable (player delivering the blow had other options)

In response to the recent [National Anthem protests in the league the past two
seasons](/wiki/U.S._national_anthem_protests_\(2016%E2%80%93present\) "U.S.
national anthem protests \(2016–present\)"), any player or staff member who is
on the field during the performance of "[The Star-Spangled
Banner](/wiki/The_Star-Spangled_Banner "The Star-Spangled Banner")" must stand
for the duration of the performance. Such players and staff members are not
required to be on the field at that time and may wait in the locker room as an
alternative. The NFL will not directly fine offending players or staff members
for defying the rule, instead fining the teams, who will in turn have power to
fine the players or staff members at their own discretion. The [National
Football League Players
Association](/wiki/National_Football_League_Players_Association "National
Football League Players Association") filed a grievance with the league over
the policy on July 11.

## 2018
deaths[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: 2018 deaths")]

The following people associated with the NFL (or
[AFL](/wiki/American_Football_League "American Football League")) have died in
2018.

### Members of the Pro Football Hall of
Fame[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Members of the Pro Football Hall of Fame")]

[Tommy McDonald](/wiki/Tommy_McDonald_\(American_football\) "Tommy McDonald
\(American football\)")

    A 1998 inductee of the [Pro Football Hall of Fame](/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame "Pro Football Hall of Fame"), McDonald played 12 seasons in the NFL, the majority of them with the [Philadelphia Eagles](/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles"), where he had the majority of his success. The six-time [Pro Bowler](/wiki/Pro_Bowl "Pro Bowl") and four-time [All-Pro](/wiki/All-Pro "All-Pro") (first or second team) led the league in both receiving yards and receiving touchdowns in 1961 and was the last non-[kicking position](/wiki/Kicking_specialist "Kicking specialist") player to play without a [facemask](/wiki/Face_mask_\(gridiron_football\) "Face mask \(gridiron football\)"). He died September 24 at the age of 84.[77]
[Jim Taylor](/wiki/Jim_Taylor_\(American_football\) "Jim Taylor \(American
football\)")

    The nine-year veteran of the [Green Bay Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers") was the first member of the team's 1961–1968 dynasty to be inducted into the Hall as a 1976 inductee. The fullback, who played from 1958 through [the first World Championship](/wiki/Super_Bowl_I "Super Bowl I"), appeared in five Pro Bowls, was named first or second team All-Pro six times, and led the league in both rushing touchdowns and yards in 1962, leading the latter category in 1961 as well. He finished his career on the inaugural roster of the [New Orleans Saints](/wiki/New_Orleans_Saints "New Orleans Saints"). He died October 13, aged 83.

### Owners[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Owners")]

[Paul Allen](/wiki/Paul_Allen "Paul Allen")

    Allen owned the [Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks "Seattle Seahawks") from 1996 until his death on October 15, at the age of 65. Allen left no wife or children, and his estate is believed to be in control of his sister, Jody Allen.[78] Allen was also the owner of the [NBA](/wiki/NBA "NBA")’s [Portland Trail Blazers](/wiki/Portland_Trail_Blazers "Portland Trail Blazers"), and part owner of [MLS](/wiki/Major_League_Soccer "Major League Soccer")’s [Seattle Sounders FC](/wiki/Seattle_Sounders_FC "Seattle Sounders FC").
[Tom Benson](/wiki/Tom_Benson "Tom Benson")

    Benson owned the [New Orleans Saints](/wiki/New_Orleans_Saints "New Orleans Saints") from 1985 until his death on March 15, at the age of 90. His wife [Gayle Benson](/wiki/Gayle_Benson "Gayle Benson") inherited the team.
[Alex Spanos](/wiki/Alex_Spanos "Alex Spanos")

    Spanos owned the [San Diego Chargers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Chargers "Los Angeles Chargers") from 1984 until his death; he had been suffering from senile dementia since 2008 and was not directly involved in the team's relocation back to Los Angeles, which was largely orchestrated by his son [Dean Spanos](/wiki/Dean_Spanos "Dean Spanos"), who will head the family consortium that inherits the team. Spanos died October 9, aged 95.

through August. Teams started training camp no earlier than 15 days before the
team's first scheduled preseason game.

The [Pro Football Hall of Fame Game](/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame_Game "Pro
Football Hall of Fame Game"), in which the [Baltimore
Ravens](/wiki/2018_Baltimore_Ravens_season "2018 Baltimore Ravens season")

## Regular
season[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Regular season")]

The 2018 [regular season](/wiki/National_Football_League_regular_season
"National Football League regular season")'s 256 games were played over a
17-week schedule that began on September 6. Each of the league's 32 teams
played a 16-game schedule, with one [bye week](/wiki/Bye_\(sports\) "Bye
\(sports\)") for each team. The slate also featured games on [Monday
Nights](/wiki/Monday_Night_Football "Monday Night Football"). There were games
played on Thursdays, including the [National Football League Kickoff
game](/wiki/National_Football_League_Kickoff_game "National Football League
Kickoff game") in prime time on September 6 and games on [Thanksgiving
Day](/wiki/NFL_on_Thanksgiving_Day "NFL on Thanksgiving Day"). The regular
season concluded with a full slate of 16 games on December 30, all of which
were intra-division matchups, as it had been since
[2010](/wiki/2010_NFL_season "2010 NFL season").

Scheduling formula

Under the NFL's current [scheduling formula](/wiki/NFL_scheduling_formula "NFL
scheduling formula"), each team plays the other three teams in its own
division twice. In addition, a team plays against all four teams in one other
division from each conference. The final two games on a team's schedule are
against the two remaining teams in the same conference that finished in the
same position in their respective divisions (e.g., the team that finished
fourth in its division will play all three other teams in the conference that
also finished fourth). The division pairings for 2018 will be as follows:

**Intra-conference**  
[AFC East](/wiki/AFC_East "AFC East") vs [AFC South](/wiki/AFC_South "AFC
South")  
[AFC West](/wiki/AFC_West "AFC West") vs [AFC North](/wiki/AFC_North "AFC
North")  
[NFC East](/wiki/NFC_East "NFC East") vs [NFC South](/wiki/NFC_South "NFC
South")  
[NFC West](/wiki/NFC_West "NFC West") vs [NFC North](/wiki/NFC_North "NFC
North")  
|  **Inter-conference**  
[AFC East](/wiki/AFC_East "AFC East") vs [NFC North](/wiki/NFC_North "NFC
North")  
[AFC North](/wiki/AFC_North "AFC North") vs [NFC South](/wiki/NFC_South "NFC
South")  
[AFC South](/wiki/AFC_South "AFC South") vs [NFC East](/wiki/NFC_East "NFC
East")  
[AFC West](/wiki/AFC_West "AFC West") vs [NFC West](/wiki/NFC_West "NFC West")  
  
---|---  
  
The entire season schedule was released on April 19, 2018. Highlights of the
2018 season include:

  * **[NFL Kickoff Game](/wiki/NFL_Kickoff_Game "NFL Kickoff Game")** : The 2018 season began with the Kickoff Game on September 6 at 8:20 p.m. EDT. The game featured the [Super Bowl LII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LII "Super Bowl LII") champion [Philadelphia Eagles](/wiki/2018_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2018 Philadelphia Eagles season") defeating the [Atlanta Falcons](/wiki/2018_Atlanta_Falcons_season "2018 Atlanta Falcons season") 18–12 and was televised on [NBC](/wiki/NFL_on_NBC "NFL on NBC").[80]
  * **[NFL International Series](/wiki/NFL_International_Series "NFL International Series")** : 
    * **NFL London Games** : Three games were played in London in 2018. All games this year were played at [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium"). The first game featured the [Oakland Raiders](/wiki/2018_Oakland_Raiders_season "2018 Oakland Raiders season"), who hosted the [Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/2018_Seattle_Seahawks_season "2018 Seattle Seahawks season") on October 14 at 1:00 p.m. EDT (6:00 p.m. [BST](/wiki/British_Summer_Time "British Summer Time")) on [Fox](/wiki/Fox_NFL "Fox NFL"). This game was originally scheduled to be played at [Tottenham Hotspur Stadium](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_Stadium "Tottenham Hotspur Stadium"), but was relocated to Wembley when it was determined that Tottenham would not be finished in time.[81] The following week, the [Los Angeles Chargers](/wiki/2018_Los_Angeles_Chargers_season "2018 Los Angeles Chargers season") hosted the [Tennessee Titans](/wiki/2018_Tennessee_Titans_season "2018 Tennessee Titans season"), on October 21 at 9:30 a.m. EDT (2:30 p.m. BST) on [CBS](/wiki/NFL_on_CBS "NFL on CBS"). And Finally, the [Jacksonville Jaguars](/wiki/2018_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2018 Jacksonville Jaguars season") hosted the defending Super Bowl Champion [Philadelphia Eagles](/wiki/2018_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2018 Philadelphia Eagles season") on October 28 at 9:30 a.m. EDT (1:30 p.m. [GMT](/wiki/Greenwich_Mean_Time "Greenwich Mean Time")) on [NFLN](/wiki/NFL_Network "NFL Network"). This was the first time the London games were played on three consecutive weeks, a move the league has taken to try to streamline their London operations.[82][83][84]
    * **NFL Mexico Game** : The NFL will play one game at [Estadio Azteca](/wiki/Estadio_Azteca "Estadio Azteca") in [Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City") in 2018, in accordance with an agreement the league announced in November 2017 to play one game at that venue each year through 2021. The game will feature the [Los Angeles Rams](/wiki/2018_Los_Angeles_Rams_season "2018 Los Angeles Rams season") hosting the [Kansas City Chiefs](/wiki/2018_Kansas_City_Chiefs_season "2018 Kansas City Chiefs season"). The game will be held on Monday, November 19, and will be televised on [ESPN](/wiki/Monday_Night_Football "Monday Night Football").[84]
  * **[Thanksgiving Day](/wiki/NFL_on_Thanksgiving_Day "NFL on Thanksgiving Day")** : As has been the case since [2006](/wiki/2006_NFL_season "2006 NFL season"), three games will be played on November 22. The 12:30 p.m. EST game will feature [Detroit Lions](/wiki/2018_Detroit_Lions_season "2018 Detroit Lions season") hosting the [Chicago Bears](/wiki/2018_Chicago_Bears_season "2018 Chicago Bears season") on [CBS](/wiki/NFL_on_CBS "NFL on CBS"). The 4:30 p.m. EST game will feature the [Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/2018_Dallas_Cowboys_season "2018 Dallas Cowboys season") hosting the [Washington Redskins](/wiki/2018_Washington_Redskins_season "2018 Washington Redskins season") on Fox. A third game, [Atlanta Falcons](/wiki/2018_Atlanta_Falcons_season "2018 Atlanta Falcons season") at [New Orleans Saints](/wiki/2018_New_Orleans_Saints_season "2018 New Orleans Saints season") starting at 8:15 p.m. EST, will be aired on NBC.
  * **[Christmas](/wiki/National_Football_League_Christmas_games "National Football League Christmas games") games**: [Christmas Day](/wiki/Christmas "Christmas"), December 25, falls on a Tuesday in 2018. Instead of moving the _[Monday Night](/wiki/ESPN_Monday_Night_Football "ESPN Monday Night Football")_ game from Christmas Eve, the game will be played at its normal time, marking only the second Monday Night game played on Christmas Eve. As is usually the case when a night game is played on Christmas Eve, both teams (the [Denver Broncos](/wiki/2018_Denver_Broncos_season "2018 Denver Broncos season") and [Oakland Raiders](/wiki/2018_Oakland_Raiders_season "2018 Oakland Raiders season")) are in the western United States, and thus the game will take place in the late afternoon local time.

### Saturday flexible
scheduling[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Saturday flexible scheduling")]

When the entire season schedule was released on April 19, 2018, the league
announced flexible scheduling for Saturday games in weeks 15 and 16. The final
kickoff times for these games will be announced no later than week 8:[85]

  * In week 15, the [Texans](/wiki/2018_Houston_Texans_season "2018 Houston Texans season")–[Jets](/wiki/2018_New_York_Jets_season "2018 New York Jets season") game will be played at 4:30 p.m., while the [Browns](/wiki/2018_Cleveland_Browns_season "2018 Cleveland Browns season")–[Broncos](/wiki/2018_Denver_Broncos_season "2018 Denver Broncos season") game will kick off at 8:20 p.m. EST, both games airing on NFL Network.
  * In week 16, two games were moved to Saturday, December 22 on the [NFL Network](/wiki/NFL_Network "NFL Network"): The [Redskins](/wiki/2018_Washington_Redskins_season "2018 Washington Redskins season")–[Titans](/wiki/2018_Tennessee_Titans_season "2018 Tennessee Titans season") game will start at 4:30 p.m. EST, while the [Ravens](/wiki/2018_Baltimore_Ravens_season "2018 Baltimore Ravens season")–[Chargers](/wiki/2018_Los_Angeles_Chargers_season "2018 Los Angeles Chargers season") game will start at 8:20 p.m. EST. The other two games that were to possibly be rescheduled, [Jaguars](/wiki/2018_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2018 Jacksonville Jaguars season")–[Dolphins](/wiki/2018_Miami_Dolphins_season "2018 Miami Dolphins season") and [Giants](/wiki/2018_New_York_Giants_season "2018 New York Giants season")–[Colts](/wiki/2018_Indianapolis_Colts_season "2018 Indianapolis Colts season"), remained on Sunday, December 23. This is the first time that games will be rescheduled to a different day (excluding games rescheduled due to severe weather).[86]

### In-season scheduling
changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: In-season scheduling changes")]

  * **Week 7:** The [Bengals](/wiki/2018_Cincinnati_Bengals_season "2018 Cincinnati Bengals season")–[Chiefs](/wiki/2018_Kansas_City_Chiefs_season "2018 Kansas City Chiefs season") game was flexed from 1:00 p.m. [ET](/wiki/Eastern_Time_Zone "Eastern Time Zone") on [CBS](/wiki/NFL_on_CBS "NFL on CBS") to the 8:20 p.m. EDT slot on [NBC](/wiki/NFL_on_NBC "NFL on NBC"), replacing the originally-scheduled [Rams](/wiki/2018_Los_Angeles_Rams_season "2018 Los Angeles Rams season")–[49ers](/wiki/2018_San_Francisco_49ers_season "2018 San Francisco 49ers season") game, which was moved to 4:25 p.m. ET on CBS. This is the earliest NBC flex game since [NBC Sports](/wiki/NBC_Sports "NBC Sports") took over the Sunday Night package in 2006.[87]
  * **Week 10:** The [Dolphins](/wiki/2018_Miami_Dolphins_season "2018 Miami Dolphins season")–[Packers](/wiki/2018_Green_Bay_Packers_season "2018 Green Bay Packers season") game was moved from 1:00 p.m. ET to 4:25 p.m. ET on CBS. Additionally, the [Cardinals](/wiki/2018_Arizona_Cardinals_season "2018 Arizona Cardinals season")–[Chiefs](/wiki/2018_Kansas_City_Chiefs_season "2018 Kansas City Chiefs season") game, originally scheduled at 1:00 p.m. ET on [Fox](/wiki/Fox_NFL "Fox NFL"), was cross-flexed to CBS, in the same time slot.[88]

## Postseason[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Postseason")]

Main article: [2018–19 NFL playoffs](/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_NFL_playoffs
"2018–19 NFL playoffs")

The 2018 playoffs will begin on the weekend of January 5–6, 2019 with the Wild
Card Playoff round. The four winners of these playoff games will visit the top
two seeds in each conference in the Divisional round games the weekend of
January 12–13. The winners of those games will advance to the Conference
championship games on January 20. The [2019 Pro Bowl](/wiki/2019_Pro_Bowl
"2019 Pro Bowl") will be held at [Camping World
Stadium](/wiki/Camping_World_Stadium "Camping World Stadium") in [Orlando,
Florida](/wiki/Orlando,_Florida "Orlando, Florida") on January 27 and will be
broadcast on ESPN and ABC. [Super Bowl LIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LIII "Super Bowl
LIII") will be held on February 3 at [Mercedes-Benz Stadium](/wiki/Mercedes-
Benz_Stadium "Mercedes-Benz Stadium") in [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta"),
on CBS.

## Records, milestones, and notable
statistics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Records, milestones, and notable statistics")]

Week 1

  * [Adrian Peterson](/wiki/Adrian_Peterson "Adrian Peterson") became the ninth player to rush for 100 touchdowns in a career.[89]

Week 2

  * [Frank Gore](/wiki/Frank_Gore "Frank Gore") passed [Curtis Martin](/wiki/Curtis_Martin "Curtis Martin") to move up to fourth on the all-time rushing yards list with 14,103 career rushing yards.[90]
  * [Patrick Mahomes](/wiki/Patrick_Mahomes "Patrick Mahomes") became the youngest quarterback to throw six touchdown passes in a game, at age 22 years and 364 days.[91]

Week 3

  * [Ryan Fitzpatrick](/wiki/Ryan_Fitzpatrick "Ryan Fitzpatrick") became the first quarterback to throw for at least 400 yards in three consecutive games.[92]

Week 4

  * [Adam Vinatieri](/wiki/Adam_Vinatieri "Adam Vinatieri") kicked his 566th career field goal, breaking the record for most field goals in a career previously held by [Morten Andersen](/wiki/Morten_Andersen "Morten Andersen").[93]

Week 5

  * [Tom Brady](/wiki/Tom_Brady "Tom Brady") threw his 500th career touchdown pass, becoming the third quarterback in NFL history to do so (joining [Brett Favre](/wiki/Brett_Favre "Brett Favre") and [Peyton Manning](/wiki/Peyton_Manning "Peyton Manning")) and becoming the first to do so playing on one team.[94] On the same pass, Brady threw a touchdown pass to a 71st different receiver, breaking an NFL record previously held by [Vinny Testaverde](/wiki/Vinny_Testaverde "Vinny Testaverde").[95]
  * [Drew Brees](/wiki/Drew_Brees "Drew Brees") became the NFL's all-time leading passer with 71,941 passing yards, surpassing Brett Favre and Peyton Manning in the process. Brees broke the record by throwing a 62-yard touchdown pass to [Tre'Quan Smith](/wiki/Tre%27Quan_Smith "Tre'Quan Smith") late in the second quarter.

Week 7

  * Drew Brees became only the third quarterback in NFL history to defeat all 32 teams, joining [Brett Favre](/wiki/Brett_Favre "Brett Favre") and [Peyton Manning](/wiki/Peyton_Manning "Peyton Manning").[96]

Week 8

  * [Adam Vinatieri](/wiki/Adam_Vinatieri "Adam Vinatieri") set the record for career points scored, with 2,550, breaking a record previously held by [Morten Andersen](/wiki/Morten_Andersen "Morten Andersen").[97]

#### Off-
season[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: Off-season")]

Team  | 2017 head coach  | 2018 replacement  | Reason for leaving  | Notes   
---|---|---|---|---  
[Arizona Cardinals](/wiki/Arizona_Cardinals "Arizona Cardinals") | [Bruce Arians](/wiki/Bruce_Arians "Bruce Arians") | [Steve Wilks](/wiki/Steve_Wilks "Steve Wilks") | Retired  | Arians retired from coaching following the 2017 season, finishing the season with a record of 8–8 (.500) and a cumulative record of 49–30–1 (.619) with two playoff appearances.[109] Wilks was hired on January 22, after serving as a defensive coach for the [Chicago Bears](/wiki/Chicago_Bears "Chicago Bears"), [San Diego Chargers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Chargers "Los Angeles Chargers"), and [Carolina Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina Panthers") since 2006. Wilks's only previous head coaching experience was at [Savannah State](/wiki/Savannah_State_Tigers_football "Savannah State Tigers football") in 1999.[110]  
[Chicago Bears](/wiki/Chicago_Bears "Chicago Bears") | [John Fox](/wiki/John_Fox_\(American_football\) "John Fox \(American football\)") | [Matt Nagy](/wiki/Matt_Nagy "Matt Nagy") | Fired  | Fox was fired after the final game of the 2017 season, finishing the season with a record of 5–11 (.313) and a cumulative record of 14–34 (.292) with no playoff appearances.[111] Nagy spent the past five seasons as an offensive assistant with the [Kansas City Chiefs](/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs "Kansas City Chiefs"), the last two as offensive coordinator; the Bears hired Nagy on January 8 and this will be his first NFL head coaching job.[112]  
[Detroit Lions](/wiki/Detroit_Lions "Detroit Lions") | [Jim Caldwell](/wiki/Jim_Caldwell_\(American_football\) "Jim Caldwell \(American football\)") | [Matt Patricia](/wiki/Matt_Patricia "Matt Patricia") | Caldwell was fired after the final game of the 2017 season, finishing the season with a record of 9–7 (.563) and a cumulative record of 36–28 (.563) with two playoff appearances, but having never won a playoff game as head coach of the Lions.[113] Patricia was hired on February 5, the day after losing [Super Bowl LII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LII "Super Bowl LII") as the [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") defensive coordinator. He had spent his entire NFL career with the Patriots, starting in 2004 as an offensive assistant before working his way up to defensive coordinator in 2012, winning 3 Super Bowls. This will be his first head coaching job.[114]  
[Indianapolis Colts](/wiki/Indianapolis_Colts "Indianapolis Colts") | [Chuck Pagano](/wiki/Chuck_Pagano "Chuck Pagano") | [Frank Reich](/wiki/Frank_Reich "Frank Reich") | Pagano was fired after the final game of the 2017 season, finishing the season with a record of 4–12 (.250), his first losing season as Colts' head coach, and a cumulative record of 53–43 (.552) with three playoff appearances.[115] On February 6, the Colts announced that they had planned to hire [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") offsenvive coordinator [Josh McDaniels](/wiki/Josh_McDaniels "Josh McDaniels") as the team's next head coach, however, McDaniels informed the Colts that he had changed his mind was returning to the Patriots.[116] The Colts then hired [Philadelphia Eagles](/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles") offensive coordinator Frank Reich, who was previously a Colts' assistant from 2008–2011. This will be Reich's first head coaching job.[117]  
[New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants") | [Ben McAdoo](/wiki/Ben_McAdoo "Ben McAdoo") | [Pat Shurmur](/wiki/Pat_Shurmur "Pat Shurmur") | McAdoo became the Giants' head coach in 2016, leading the Giants to a 13–15 (.464) record over parts of two seasons with one playoff appearance. After accruing a 2–10 (.167) record and benching starter [Eli Manning](/wiki/Eli_Manning "Eli Manning") during the season, he was fired on December 4, 2017, and replaced in the interim by defensive coordinator Steve Spagnuolo.[118] Shurmur was announced as the Giants' new head coach on January 22. He had previously served as the head coach of the [Cleveland Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns") from 2011 to 2012, compiling a record of 9–23 (.281), and an offensive coach for the [Philadelphia Eagles](/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles") and [Minnesota Vikings](/wiki/Minnesota_Vikings "Minnesota Vikings") since 2013.[119]  
[Oakland Raiders](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland Raiders") | [Jack Del Rio](/wiki/Jack_Del_Rio "Jack Del Rio") | [Jon Gruden](/wiki/Jon_Gruden "Jon Gruden") | Del Rio was fired after the 2017 season, finishing the season with a record of 6–10 (.375) and a cumulative record of 25–23 (.521) with one playoff appearance.[120] Gruden, who previously coached the Raiders from 1998 to 2001 and won a [Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVII "Super Bowl XXXVII") with the [Tampa Bay Buccaneers](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers "Tampa Bay Buccaneers") at the end of the [2002 season](/wiki/2002_NFL_season "2002 NFL season"), confirmed on-air on January 6, that he would be returning to the team as coach. He had spent the previous nine seasons as an on-air analyst for _[Monday Night Football](/wiki/Monday_Night_Football "Monday Night Football")_.[121]  
[Tennessee Titans](/wiki/Tennessee_Titans "Tennessee Titans") | [Mike Mularkey](/wiki/Mike_Mularkey "Mike Mularkey") | [Mike Vrabel](/wiki/Mike_Vrabel "Mike Vrabel") | Mutual decision  | Mularkey and the Titans agreed to part ways after they "couldn't come to an agreement over the future," two days after the Titans' playoff loss to the Patriots. Mularkey had a cumulative record of 20–21 (.488) with one playoff appearance in parts of three seasons with the Titans and guided Tennessee to back-to-back 9–7 (.563) records in his two years as the team's full-time head coach.[122] Vrabel spent the past three seasons as a defensive assistant with the [Houston Texans](/wiki/Houston_Texans "Houston Texans"), the last as defensive coordinator; the Titans hired Vrabel on January 20 and this will be his first NFL head coaching job.[123]

His dismissal follows a power struggle with offensive coordinator [Todd Haley](/wiki/Todd_Haley "Todd Haley") (who was fired at the same time) and the team's 25th [consecutive loss](/wiki/Losing_streak "Losing streak") away from home; Jackson failed to win a single road game during his tenure and [lost every game in 2017](/wiki/List_of_winless_seasons "List of winless seasons").[124] Williams, the team's defensive coordinator, was previously the head coach of the [Buffalo Bills](/wiki/Buffalo_Bills "Buffalo Bills") from 2001 to 2003, with a record of 17–31 (.354).

He was replaced in the interim by assistant general manager Kevin Abrams.[131] Dave Gettleman, previously general manager of the [Carolina Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina Panthers") and a 14-year veteran of the Giants' front office (from 1999 to 2012), was hired on December 28, 2017.[132]  
[Buffalo Bills](/wiki/Buffalo_Bills "Buffalo Bills") | President  | [Russ Brandon](/wiki/Russ_Brandon "Russ Brandon") | [Kim Pegula](/wiki/Kim_Pegula "Kim Pegula") | Resigned  | Brandon resigned his position on May 1, 2018. A newspaper report claimed that Brandon was the subject of an internal investigation regarding his personal conduct and workplace behavior, which neither the Bills nor Brandon mentioned in separate statements regarding his departure; Brandon stated he is seeking other opportunities after spending 20 years with the Bills franchise. He was immediately succeeded by co-owner Kim Pegula.[133]  
  
## Stadiums[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Stadiums")]

Two teams, the [Carolina Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina
Panthers") and [Oakland Raiders](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland Raiders"), are
entering the final year of their lease agreements with their current stadium.

### Carolina
Panthers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Carolina Panthers")]

On December 17, 2017, [Jerry Richardson](/wiki/Jerry_Richardson "Jerry
Richardson"), the Panthers' founding owner, announced he was putting the team
up for sale.[134][135] Richardson had previously indicated the team would be
put up for sale after his death,[136] but Richardson was accused of paying
[hush money](/wiki/Hush_money "Hush money") to cover up questionable conduct,
including racial slurs and sexually suggestive requests of employees,
hastening Richardson's decision.[137] The Panthers' lease on [Bank of America
Stadium](/wiki/Bank_of_America_Stadium "Bank of America Stadium") expires
after the 2018 season,[138] which would allow any incoming owner to relocate
the team out of [Charlotte, North Carolina](/wiki/Charlotte,_North_Carolina
"Charlotte, North Carolina"), to another market if they so desired, only being
liable for the remaining debt from stadium renovation. At an estimated $35
million, the debt payment would be a small expense compared to the relocation
fee the NFL charged for the two teams that relocated in 2016 and 2017.[139]
The two most likely candidates to buy the team as of May 2018 were [David
Tepper](/wiki/David_Tepper "David Tepper"), a hedge fund manager with a higher
net worth and a minority stake in the [Pittsburgh
Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") but fewer ties to
Charlotte; and [Ben Navarro](/wiki/Ben_Navarro "Ben Navarro"), a financial
services CEO based in Charlotte who had the backing of Richardson's only
living son.[140] Tepper was announced as the new owner on May 16, with the
announcement coming in time for the league to vote on his bid at the owners
meeting on May 19.[141] The sale closed on July 9 with Richardson-era chief
operating officer Tina Becker (who ran the franchise after Richardson stepped
away from operations) resigning. Tepper immediately stated the franchise would
retain the Carolina Panthers name for the time being, but that a new stadium
would likely be necessary; he stated that he hoped to build said stadium in
Charlotte but would not guarantee the team remains there, claiming he did not
know enough about the situation to guarantee the team stays in the Charlotte
area.[142]

### Oakland
Raiders[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: Oakland Raiders")]

Main article: [Oakland Raiders relocation to Las
Vegas](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders_relocation_to_Las_Vegas "Oakland Raiders
relocation to Las Vegas")

The Raiders, prior to the 2017 season, committed to relocating to [Las
Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas "Las Vegas"), [Nevada](/wiki/Nevada "Nevada"), once a
new [stadium](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Stadium "Las Vegas Stadium") is constructed for
them in 2020. In 2016, the Raiders signed a three-year extension with the
[Oakland Coliseum](/wiki/Oakland-Alameda_County_Coliseum "Oakland-Alameda
County Coliseum").[143] The Raiders could choose to stay in the Oakland
Coliseum for 2019 with another year-to-year extension or move to [Sam Boyd
Stadium](/wiki/Sam_Boyd_Stadium "Sam Boyd Stadium") in Las Vegas, which is
undersized but (because of the [Los Angeles
Chargers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Chargers "Los Angeles Chargers")' use of the even
smaller [StubHub Center](/wiki/StubHub_Center "StubHub Center")) would not be
the smallest stadium in the NFL. Management at the Oakland Coliseum has
indicated they are unwilling to extend their agreement with the Raiders after
2018, which could force the team to move to Sam Boyd Stadium in 2019.[144] In
order to secure another season in [Oakland,
California](/wiki/Oakland,_California "Oakland, California"), Coliseum
management indicated in September 2017 that the Raiders would need to offer
major concessions to compensate for the financial losses the Coliseum incurs
by hosting Raiders games.[145]

### Naming rights
agreements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=34
"Edit section: Naming rights agreements")]

#### Arizona
Cardinals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Arizona Cardinals")]

On September 4, University of Phoenix Stadium, the home field of the [Arizona
Cardinals](/wiki/Arizona_Cardinals "Arizona Cardinals"), was renamed [State
Farm Stadium](/wiki/State_Farm_Stadium "State Farm Stadium"). The [naming
rights](/wiki/Naming_rights "Naming rights") agreement is for 18 years;
however, the cost of the deal was not disclosed.[146]

#### Denver
Broncos[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=36 "Edit
section: Denver Broncos")]

On June 20, the [Denver Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos")' home
stadium was renamed [Broncos Stadium at Mile
High](/wiki/Broncos_Stadium_at_Mile_High "Broncos Stadium at Mile High").[147]
The sporting goods chain [Sports Authority](/wiki/Sports_Authority "Sports
Authority") had held naming rights to the stadium's field (as "Sports
Authority Field at Mile High") but [had gone out of
business](/wiki/Retail_apocalypse "Retail apocalypse") in 2016. The previous
signage referring to Sports Authority was removed in March.[148][149] The
Broncos hope to resell the naming rights to the stadium to another corporate
sponsor in the near future.[147]

#### Jacksonville
Jaguars[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=37 "Edit
section: Jacksonville Jaguars")]

On February 16, EverBank Field, the home field of the [Jacksonville
Jaguars](/wiki/Jacksonville_Jaguars "Jacksonville Jaguars"), was renamed [TIAA
Bank Field](/wiki/TIAA_Bank_Field "TIAA Bank Field"), after [TIAA](/wiki/TIAA
"TIAA")'s 2017 acquisition of [EverBank](/wiki/EverBank "EverBank"). The
naming rights agreement was for 10 years and $43 million.[150]

## Uniforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=38
"Edit section: Uniforms")]

### Color Rush
discontinuation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=39
"Edit section: Color Rush discontinuation")]

The [Color Rush](/wiki/NFL_Color_Rush "NFL Color Rush") program was
discontinued, and teams were no longer required to wear the special uniforms
for _Thursday Night Football_. Initial plans, which were finalized at the
league's owners meeting in May, are for teams to have the option to continue
using the existing [Nike](/wiki/Nike,_Inc. "Nike, Inc.") designs for the
program as standard [third jerseys](/wiki/Third_jersey "Third
jersey").[151][152]

### Uniform
changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=40 "Edit
section: Uniform changes")]

  * [Chicago Bears](/wiki/Chicago_Bears "Chicago Bears"): The Bears brought back their orange alternate jerseys that the team wore from 2005–2009 and 2011. The team announced that the orange uniforms will be worn twice in 2018, and the team will use the navy blue "[Monsters of the Midway](/wiki/Monsters_of_the_Midway "Monsters of the Midway")" throwbacks for one game.[153]
  * [Jacksonville Jaguars](/wiki/Jacksonville_Jaguars "Jacksonville Jaguars"): On April 19, the Jaguars simplified their uniforms in a similar look they had used before 2013. Gold was also eliminated from their previous jerseys and the gradient black and gold helmet was reverted to an all-black gloss shell.[154]
  * [Los Angeles Rams](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Rams "Los Angeles Rams"): On July 27, the Rams announced that due to overwhelming fan demand the NFL relaxed their alternate uniform policy and has permitted them to use their royal blue and yellow throwbacks as their color jerseys for the next two seasons until they present entirely new ones in 2020. When using their white jerseys, the team will still have to use their current set carried over from St. Louis albeit from slight modifications they made to them in 2017.[155]
  * [Miami Dolphins](/wiki/Miami_Dolphins "Miami Dolphins"): On April 19, the Dolphins simplified their uniform outlines to take after their classic aqua-and-orange look. Dark blue was removed from everything but the logo.[156]
  * [Tennessee Titans](/wiki/Tennessee_Titans "Tennessee Titans"): On April 4, the Titans introduced new uniforms. Most prominent among the changes is the helmet, which is changing from the white color the team had used since the 1970s (as the Houston Oilers) to navy blue. The color patterns are also simplified, with a new number typeface inspired both by Greek lettering and the shape of the state of Tennessee.[157]

### Throwback
uniforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=41
"Edit section: Throwback uniforms")]

  * [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers"): On May 30, the Steelers unveiled a throwback uniform, that was worn in the late 1970s. Team owner [Art Rooney II](/wiki/Art_Rooney_II "Art Rooney II") announced that the team will wear the uniforms for one game.[158]
  * [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers"): On May 23, 49ers unveiled a new all-white throwback uniform, that was worn in 1994, the year the team won its most recent [Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXIX "Super Bowl XXIX"). The team announced that they will be worn for two games.[159]

### Patches[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=42
"Edit section: Patches")]

  * [Green Bay Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers"): On April 9, the Packers unveiled a patch to commemorate their 100th season.[160]
  * [Indianapolis Colts](/wiki/Indianapolis_Colts "Indianapolis Colts"): On April 10, the Colts unveiled a patch to commemorate their 35th season in Indianapolis.[161]
  * [New Orleans Saints](/wiki/New_Orleans_Saints "New Orleans Saints"): On August 9, the Saints unveiled a patch to commemorate the passing of Tom Benson.[162]

## Media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=43
"Edit section: Media")]

### Broadcast
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=44 "Edit
section: Broadcast rights")]

####
Television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=45
"Edit section: Television")]

This will be the fifth year under the current broadcast contracts with
[ESPN](/wiki/Monday_Night_Football "Monday Night Football"),
[CBS](/wiki/NFL_on_CBS "NFL on CBS"), [Fox](/wiki/Fox_NFL "Fox NFL"), and
[NBC](/wiki/NFL_on_NBC "NFL on NBC"). This includes "cross-flexing"
(switching) Sunday afternoon games between CBS and Fox before or during the
season (regardless of the conference of the visiting team). NBC will continue
to air _[Sunday Night Football](/wiki/NBC_Sunday_Night_Football "NBC Sunday
Night Football")_ , the annual [Kickoff
game](/wiki/National_Football_League_Kickoff_Game "National Football League
Kickoff Game"), and the primetime Thanksgiving game. ESPN will continue to air
_[Monday Night Football](/wiki/Monday_Night_Football "Monday Night Football")_
and the [Pro Bowl](/wiki/Pro_Bowl "Pro Bowl"). CBS will broadcast [Super Bowl
LIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LIII "Super Bowl LIII").

On January 31, the NFL announced that Fox had acquired the broadcast
television rights to the _[Thursday Night
Football](/wiki/Thursday_Night_Football "Thursday Night Football")_ package
under a five-year deal (aligned with the remainder of the NFL's current
broadcast contracts). Fox will air 11 games, along with the [2018 NFL
Draft](/wiki/2018_NFL_Draft "2018 NFL Draft") (the first time the event has
aired on over-the-air television),[163] in simulcast with [NFL
Network](/wiki/NFL_Network "NFL Network"),[164][165] with the remaining games
in the package airing exclusively on NFL Network to satisfy its carriage
contracts.[166] CBS and NBC had made bids to renew their previous contracts
(CBS had held the rights since 2014, joined by NBC since 2016), but were
reluctant to pay a higher rights fee due to the league's ratings
downturn.[167]

#### Digital[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=46
"Edit section: Digital")]

The NFL agreed to an extension of its digital rights agreement with [Verizon
Communications](/wiki/Verizon_Communications "Verizon Communications") under a
5-year, $2.5 billion deal. Unlike the previous deal, it no longer includes
exclusivity for streaming in-market and nationally televised NFL games on
mobile devices with screens 7 inches (18 cm) or less in size (such as
[smartphones](/wiki/Smartphone "Smartphone")), in order to account for changes
in viewing habits, but still includes enhanced access to highlights and other
digital content for Verizon-owned properties. In addition, Verizon announced
that it would no longer make these streams exclusive to [Verizon
Wireless](/wiki/Verizon_Wireless "Verizon Wireless") subscribers, and would
leverage its [portfolio of media brands](/wiki/Oath_Inc. "Oath Inc.") (such as
[Yahoo!](/wiki/Yahoo! "Yahoo!"), which it acquired in 2017) to distribute them
to a larger audience.[168][169] All of the NFL's current television partners
have added mobile streaming rights (which were previously reserved to Verizon)
to their existing contracts for the 2018 season.[170][171] Under the terms of
the agreement, Verizon must give the majority of the advertising revenue to
the broadcast partners.[172]

On April 26, 2018, the NFL announced that it had reached a two-year extension
of its agreement with [Amazon](/wiki/Amazon_\(company\) "Amazon \(company\)")
for shared digital rights to the _Thursday Night Football_ games simulcast
with Fox, with a 15% increase in rights fees. To fulfill a request that the
streams be available freely, the games will also be made available on
[Twitch](/wiki/Twitch.tv "Twitch.tv"), an Amazon-owned streaming service that
was originally designed for video game streaming.[173]

#### Radio[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=47
"Edit section: Radio")]

Both of the NFL's national radio contracts, [Westwood
One](/wiki/NFL_on_Westwood_One_Sports "NFL on Westwood One Sports") for
English language[174] and [Entravision](/wiki/Entravision "Entravision") for
Spanish language,[175] expired after the 2017 season. Westwood One's parent
company [Cumulus Media](/wiki/Cumulus_Media "Cumulus Media") filed for
bankruptcy in November 2017[176] and began terminating national broadcast
contracts and sports agreements in January 2018,[177][178] putting any
contract extensions on hold. The company emerged from bankruptcy on June 4,
2018.[179]

With the release of the 2018 schedule, NFL.com listed [ESPN Deportes
Radio](/wiki/ESPN_Deportes_Radio "ESPN Deportes Radio") (which had shared NFL
rights with Entravision in 2017 and had carried Super Bowl LII[180]) as the
league's national Spanish-language broadcaster. The national English-language
broadcaster was still identified as Westwood One, which Westwood One has also
confirmed;[181] no press release has been issued in regard to a contract
extension with that network, and it is unknown when the current arrangement
was signed or when it will end. Additionally, Westwood One removed Sunday
afternoon games from their package, instead focusing on the primetime matchups
as well as the postseason. [SportsUSA](/wiki/Sports_USA_Radio_Network "Sports
USA Radio Network"), [Compass](/wiki/Compass_Media_Networks "Compass Media
Networks") and [ESPN Radio](/wiki/ESPN_Radio "ESPN Radio"), which also has
broadcast select Sunday afternoon NFL games, will continue to do so.[182]

Only one game into the pre-season, [Indianapolis
Colts](/wiki/Indianapolis_Colts "Indianapolis Colts") announcer [Bob
Lamey](/wiki/Bob_Lamey "Bob Lamey"), who had been with the team for most of
the time since their [1984 relocation from
Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore_Colts_relocation_to_Indianapolis "Baltimore Colts
relocation to Indianapolis"), retired suddenly after a complaint of him using
a racial slur in the 1980s was revealed. Sideline reporter Matt Taylor was
named his _de facto_ replacement for the season.[183]

### Personnel
changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=48 "Edit
section: Personnel changes")]

All four broadcast partners will employ rules analysts for the 2018 season,
citing changes in the league's rules that have become too complicated for its
broadcast teams to handle.[66] To be precise, NBC hired [Terry
McAulay](/wiki/Terry_McAulay "Terry McAulay") to be their rules analyst for
SNF and [NBC’s coverage of Notre Dame
Football](/wiki/Notre_Dame_Football_on_NBC "Notre Dame Football on NBC"). CBS
hired [Gene Steratore](/wiki/Gene_Steratore "Gene Steratore") to fill their
rules analyst position, filling a position that had been vacant since CBS
released [Mike Carey](/wiki/Mike_Carey_\(American_football\) "Mike Carey
\(American football\)") in 2015; because Steratore also officiates college
basketball, he will also be used as a rules analyst for [the networks’ NCAA
Basketball coverage](/wiki/NCAA_March_Madness_\(CBS/Turner\) "NCAA March
Madness \(CBS/Turner\)"). ESPN hired [Jeff Triplette](/wiki/Jeff_Triplette
"Jeff Triplette") for MNF. And Fox kept both [Mike Pereira](/wiki/Mike_Pereira
"Mike Pereira") and [Dean Blandino](/wiki/Dean_Blandino "Dean Blandino").
Additionally, Pereira assists with Fox’s Thursday Night Football Coverage.

ESPN will introduce a fully new broadcast team for _Monday Night Football_.
[Joe Tessitore](/wiki/Joe_Tessitore "Joe Tessitore") will replace [Sean
McDonough](/wiki/Sean_McDonough "Sean McDonough") as lead play-by-play man;
McDonough will remain with ESPN as a college football announcer.[184][185]
With previous color analyst [Jon Gruden](/wiki/Jon_Gruden "Jon Gruden")
returning to coaching, _Monday Night Football_ hired [Jason
Witten](/wiki/Jason_Witten "Jason Witten") and [Booger
McFarland](/wiki/Booger_McFarland "Booger McFarland") as their color
commentators; while McFarland offers his commentary from the sidelines, he
fills a role similar to the "non-football" player position that _Monday Night
Football_ has traditionally relied upon in its past three-person booths (such
as [Howard Cosell](/wiki/Howard_Cosell "Howard Cosell"), [Dennis
Miller](/wiki/Dennis_Miller "Dennis Miller") and [Tony
Kornheiser](/wiki/Tony_Kornheiser "Tony Kornheiser")).[186] [Lisa
Salters](/wiki/Lisa_Salters "Lisa Salters"), the sideline reporter, carries
over from the previous broadcast team.[187] [Jeff
Triplette](/wiki/Jeff_Triplette "Jeff Triplette") will replace [Gerald
Austin](/wiki/Gerald_Austin "Gerald Austin") as rules analyst.[188]

Fox initially had planned to hire a new broadcast team for its _Thursday Night
Football_ , making an overture to [Peyton Manning](/wiki/Peyton_Manning
"Peyton Manning") to serve as color commentator. Since Manning declined the
offer, the network announced that it will be placing its existing lead
broadcast team of [Joe Buck](/wiki/Joe_Buck "Joe Buck") and [Troy
Aikman](/wiki/Troy_Aikman "Troy Aikman") on the package, reducing the number
of games the duo will call on Sundays (Buck and Aikman will only call the
nationally televised "America's Game of the Week" telecasts on Sundays).[189]
A version of _[Fox NFL Sunday](/wiki/Fox_NFL_Sunday "Fox NFL Sunday")_ will
serve as the [lead-in](/wiki/Lead-in "Lead-in") to _Thursday Night Football_ ,
albeit without [Curt Menefee](/wiki/Curt_Menefee "Curt Menefee") or [Jimmy
Johnson](/wiki/Jimmy_Johnson_\(American_football_coach\) "Jimmy Johnson
\(American football coach\)"); the show will instead be hosted by panelist
[Michael Strahan](/wiki/Michael_Strahan "Michael Strahan") from New York City,
displacing [Rich Eisen](/wiki/Rich_Eisen "Rich Eisen"), the studio host for
Thursday night pregame since the package's inception in 2006.[190] Strahan
will be joined by fellow Fox colleagues [Terry Bradshaw](/wiki/Terry_Bradshaw
"Terry Bradshaw") and [Howie Long](/wiki/Howie_Long "Howie Long").

In previous seasons, Buck did not call any NFL games during late October,
working [Major League Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League
Baseball") playoff games instead. For 2018, Fox coordinated its schedule with
MLB so that none of its scheduled broadcasts would land on a Thursday (Fox
carries the [NLCS](/wiki/National_League_Championship_Series "National League
Championship Series") and the World Series), so Buck will continue to
broadcast both sports, crisscrossing the country in seven cities over a 22-day
period.[191]

In addition, NBC will introduce a new studio team for _[Football Night in
America](/wiki/Football_Night_in_America "Football Night in America")_. [Mike
Tirico](/wiki/Mike_Tirico "Mike Tirico"), who was the on-site host and
secondary play-by-play announcer in 2017, became the show's studio host from
[Stanford, Connecticut](/wiki/Stanford,_Connecticut "Stanford, Connecticut"),
with [Liam McHugh](/wiki/Liam_McHugh "Liam McHugh") moving into Tirico's
former role. [Dan Patrick](/wiki/Dan_Patrick "Dan Patrick"), who had been the
studio host for _FNiA_ since 2008, declined to sign a long-term contract and
left NBC.[192]

On radio, [Kurt Warner](/wiki/Kurt_Warner "Kurt Warner") will replace [Boomer
Esiason](/wiki/Boomer_Esiason "Boomer Esiason") as the color commentator for
Westwood One's _Monday Night Football_ broadcasts, after Esiason had filled
the role for the previous 18 years. Esiason will continue as a studio host for
CBS, along with his existing duties on the [CBS Sports
Network](/wiki/CBS_Sports_Network "CBS Sports Network")-simulcast _[Boomer and
Gio](/wiki/Boomer_and_Gio "Boomer and Gio")_ from [WFAN](/wiki/WFAN_\(AM\)
"WFAN \(AM\)").[193]

In a surprise announcement made two days before its first game, Amazon
announced it would provide its own broadcast team for its eleven games, with
[Hannah Storm](/wiki/Hannah_Storm "Hannah Storm") and [Andrea
Kremer](/wiki/Andrea_Kremer "Andrea Kremer") serving as the lead broadcast
team. The announcement makes Kremer the first-ever female color analyst for an
NFL game, the first time a game has been broadcast with no men involved in the
broadcast team, and the first time since [Tony
Kornheiser](/wiki/Tony_Kornheiser "Tony Kornheiser") left _Monday Night
Football_ that the color analyst had no coaching or playing experience. Amazon
will offer the standard Fox broadcast team, a British broadcasting team, and a
Spanish language feed as alternate audio choices.[194]

### Start time
changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_NFL_season&action=edit&section=49 "Edit
section: Start time changes")]

The start times for Thursday, Sunday, and Monday Night Football broadcasts
will be moved up 5 to 15 minutes. Thursday and Sunday Night games will now
kick off at 8:20 p.m. ET, while Monday Night games will now kick off at 8:15
p.m. ET.[85]
